comments.text:
I know that it has meaning, and I agree that Fox was saying that it had no

 But I doubt most of the people watching the video in North America would

comments.author: Sarah H

comments.text:
no, it DOES have meaning, all you have to do is look up a translation. Fox

is incorrect
comments.author: Liv RP

comments.text:
"that without intelligible words"

Is Fox News even aware that other languages than English exist?﻿
comments.author: Alica Ljungberg

comments.text:
I usually enjoy your videos, and I am no fan of O'Reilley, but in this 
instance you are sadly missing the point. Do you not get that the the lack 
of meaning they are talking about is referencing all the non-korean 
speaking people who are enjoying the music without understanding the 
lyrics? It appears that you are so eager to criticize Fox that you don't 
even try to understand their point. You can do better.﻿
comments.author: Max Müller

comments.text:
That's funny, I looked up the translation shortly after this came on the 
radio....
comments.author: Bob Jones

comments.text:
+Max Müller I'm not sure anyone was implying that Mr. O'Reilly didn't 
understand that the song was in a different language, it was more, based on 
the fact that the song is in a different language and refers to a different 
culture, a lot of what they said (particularly the psychologist guest) was 
just silly.  I mean "without intelligible words to some extent" is a 
laughable comment.  Also, the nonsense about the dangers of the song 
because it wasn't meaningful -- implying this is some sort of new ominous 
trend of today -- is hilarious as well.  Pop music comes up with 
meaningless big hits constantly.  MairzyDoats, from 1944, anyone?  ("Mares 
eat oats and does eat oats and little lambs eat ivy. A kid'le eat ivy too, 
wouldn't you?).  "Bird bird bird, bird is the word" (1963) anyone?  A long, 
rich tradition of absolute nonsense that has hurt no one.  It's not ominous 
or a statement on society, it's "fun".  What a concept.  Also, the 
assumption on the part of these wagging tongues on Fox, that absolutely 
nobody has a clue as to the satirical "meaning" of the song, such as it is, 
is as relevant and trenchant as O'Reilly pointing out that he's known lots 
of "Sy's", and none of them look like this "little fat guy from Yong Yang" 
- it's not so much offensive as so damn "FOX"-y.  Bleahhhh.
comments.author: trysometruth

comments.text:
+trysometruth I think they are trying to explain why the video/song became 
the most popular song online ever. And their explanation is that people, 
and most of the people who liked the song are non-korean speaking people, 
want songs that don't try to have a deeper meaning. And that this is why a 
korean song with a good beat and a chorus that is catchy even when you 
don't understand it, could become so popular. I further think that they 
don't take care to mention that they are talking about non-korean speaking 
people because, as you probably know, Fox News does not care about anyone 
except english speaking americans. I'm not really sure if Bill O'Reilly, in 
general, really is stupid; or if he is just willfully ignorant and lies a 
lot; but I do think that believing that he does not understand that the 
song is in a different language is underestimating EVEN him.

+Ovo124  I'm not really sure what you are reacting to. All I said about 
songs in a different language was that people seem to like some of them 
despite the fact that they do not understand the lyrics. I did not ascribe 
any value to that observation, either negative or positive.
comments.author: Max Müller

comments.text:
What the fuck?!?! That would go for ANY song in a different language. 
Should Americans only listen to English songs?
comments.author: Ovo124

comments.text:
Nice softball interpretation.  They (Bill O'Reilley and his guest) never 
once said that it was meaningless *only to non-Korean speaking people* (who 
were apparently too lazy to look up the meaning, and who ignored the many 
articles that came out on the song when it first exploded on YouTube).  The 
fact that O'Reilly said "this is a little fat guy from Yong Yang or 
someplace" shows how little effort he put into understanding where Psy 
comes from.  Then the good "doctor" blathers that "the most popular music, 
apparently is *that without intelligible words, to some extent*."  He never 
once indicates that he's aware that the words happen to be in a different 
language than the one he understands.  They both come off as arrogant 
douchebags.  Cenk was simply pointing out that obvious fact.
comments.author: trysometruth

comments.text:
Didn't Psy say that  Gangnam style was about people who worked all day then 
went and partied at night?   So it does have a meaning..  Fox news are some 
dumb motherfuckers.﻿
comments.author: Silkfox

comments.text:
I get that Gangnam style became popular because of its catchiness and silly 
music video, but it it bothers me that O'Reilly called the song and music 
video "meaningless" when in fact had he done a little research (not even) 
on the songs lyrics, he would've realized that the entire song's lyrics is 
playing on a satirical view of Gangnam (which btw is a district in Seoul). 
I don't wanna get into analyzing the music video (look it up yourself), but 
this guy just debunked and so-called "critically analyzed" a music video 
without even bothering to look up the song's translated lyrics. Probably 
because it was in a foreign language and therefore he safely assumed it was 
okay to make uneducated claims about the song. Also, don't people often 
search for "meaning" in music videos through their lyrics?? I just don't 
get where this guy's claims are coming from?????? The stupidity of Fox once 
again.﻿
comments.author: DuetxxLuxe

comments.text:
Nothing new to see here people - move along. When I was a kid it was those 
evil Beatles and Rolling Stones, then worse yet the backward messages from 
Satan on Led Zepplin albums. Before that, it was Elvis, before that it was 
swing music, today it's rap and apparently Sye that are going to melt our 
children's brains and keep the country from winning the war.﻿

comments.author: UndeadSon

comments.text:
The song Gangnam is basically about a part of the city where he is from. 
When he says Oppa is Gangnam style he is saying "older brother is that 
neighborhood." When Psy says "hey sexy lady" he is basically calling the 
neighborhood a lady as when people revup a car and say "she is humming 
beautifully." If that makes sense. The rest is just Psy continuing the same 
comparison. "her heart warms up hotter at night" aka "the neighborhood gets 
more joyace as night closes in and people go out to have fun on the town.﻿
comments.author: Brad B.

comments.text:
Most importantly, this song is a satire, most people don't know this but 
can't blame them since most people don't understand Korean culture
comments.author: H Tsui

comments.text:
I've been watching various Korean dramas and have gained an interest in 
Korean culture through that lens, however distorted.  After seeing Korean 
attitudes reflected about the dichotomy of their current economic state 
with extremely wealthy down the block from extremely poor, I knew right 
away that Gangnam Style was a commentary on this. South Koreans went from 
eating dirt (literally) to buying espresso in a very short time so the 
culture of the rich is an especially interesting topic there.  The beat is 
really enjoyable too.  Music can be just that; something that makes you 
feel good and gets you moving.  All it takes is knowledge and a natural 
interest in the world to not be like a Fox News presenter.﻿
comments.author: Sarah K

comments.text:
I thought the same thing as O'Reilly at first about the words being 
gibberish. You know what I did? I searched Gangnam Style lyrics and then, 
assuming they were written mostly in Korean, searched for a translation and 
found one. It took me all of five minutes. It's ridiculous how little 
checking that took and that O'Reilly apparently didn't even do a simple 
lyrics search.﻿

of itself.

comments.author: Mindaugas V

comments.text:
Almost all of pop music throughout pop music history hasn't required 
"skill" to listen to.  Yet the world still spins, people are still able to 
function, communicate, build things, and help each other.  That is simply 
the true face of pop music, and I quote from a venerable old classic from 
long ago, in English, no less: "Goody goody gum drops, my heart is doing 
flip flops - see what love can do?  I'm gonna shout it from the rooftops, 
goody goody gum drops, with a girl like you!"  Feel the skill, the deep 
meaning, the craft.  IT'S FRIGGIN' POP MUSIC.

comments.author: iNXTGeek

comments.text:
Funny thing is the song is a satire…  Usually, satires do - in fact - have 
meaning behind them as they tend to poke fun at a certain aspect(s) of 
society.  I think Bill'O and Dr. Schmuck Who-Gives-a-Fuck MD were just 
being willfully ignorant and/or pandering to their audience, who are 
(generally) laughably stupid.﻿
comments.author: TriStar

comments.text:
Hate to break it to you, but I wasn't mad in the least when I wrote that 
comment.  On the contrary, I was actually quite amused at your failed 
attempt at intelligent insight.  I had a pretty good laugh at your expense, 
so thank you and please do continue being the stupidest person on the 
internet.  By the way, your comment is that of a defeated, defenseless, 
small-minded child.  How does it feel to get owned so hard by a complete 
stranger?  You worthless nothing.
comments.author: TriStar

comments.text:
First of all, you're a dense cunt.  Ignorance is a lack of knowledge -- 
stupidity is a lack of judgement/good sense. Furthermore, 'ignorance' is 
*literally* a synonym of 'stupidity', you worthlessly idiotic nothing.  But 
that's all beside the point, because I never even equated ignorance to 
stupidity -- I said Bill and Dr. Who-Gives-A-Shit were ignorant, and Fox 
viewers were (generally) stupid.  Clearly, you fit into the latter category 
like a glove as well.

Secondly, did I repeat what they said in the video?  Really?  Please, if 
you'd be so kind, direct me to the part of this vid where they said that 
the song was a satire. 

You and your comment are the epitome of the word 'fail' … get off youtube 
and make a positive impact on the world for a change (by killing yourself). 
 After all, it's what Santa would want.
comments.author: TriStar

comments.author: orionpax

comments.text:
in a way, i kind of agree with them, not about Gangnam style, because it's 
just satire and i think they're over analyzing it.  But i have 2 young 
children and i have seen the types of cartoons that are on tv and books 
that are out for children these days, and it is true, they really aren't 
there to try and portray a message anymore, it's all just about distraction 
and entertainment.which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it does make me 
feel kind of sad, because when i was a kid, the stories in cartoons 
actually had substance and impact, but now it's just all about silliness 
for the few western cartoons that are actually left. Now a days kids 
cartoons are limited to anime (which i won't complain about, because most 
of them are the same ones i watched as a kid and they haven't really 
changed)  and stupid stuff like Adventure time, Scaredy squirrel, jimmy two 
shoes and the like. the only intelligent cartoons i have seen for kids are 
on Disney junior, but after the age of 5, most kids don't want to watch 
that stuff anymore.﻿

comments.text:
My point was... I believe this is an age/generational difference "issue" 
NOT racism. The Young Turks arrogantly make wild and irresponsible 
accusations of racism as though they have the authority to determine what 
is or is not racist. They do not. Where is the accountability? Beware of 
propaganda masquerading as journalism.
